paragraphs.text: Seven ways to stay married.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Five years ago, I went on a search to answer the question: What can people do to have a happy, fulfilling, lifelong marriage?
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: I sought out an unusual source of information, however
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I didn't ask psychologists or consult self-help gurus
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Instead
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: I decided to go to the people with the most experience: older Americans who have been married 50, 60, 70 years and more(described in my recent book, "30 Lessons for Loving" (Hudson Street Press, January 8, 2015)
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: I believed that the view from the finish line of marriage would be uniquely valuable
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: - and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: I wasn't disappointed
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: America's elders provided a treasure trove of lessons, tips, and advice for how to find the right mate and keep the spark alive over decades
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Here are seven things they would like younger people to know
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: - from those
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: who are looking for a relationships to those who are in one and striving to make it last "as long as you both shall live."
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: Marriage is hard
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Even though this is not on the minds of couples getting engaged or standing at the altar
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the elders want you to know that marriage is hard
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It's tough - both because of the range of stresses and problems that confront all couples
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but also because of the fundamental difficulty of merging two separate and different people into one single life
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I learned that they see marriage as a discipline, like becoming an athlete or a musician
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: you never reach perfection
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: you are constantly learning
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: you sacrifice short-term gain for something more rewarding later on
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But marriage for a lifetime is worth it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Being with someone for a half century or more, they told me, is incredibly good
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: It is a sublime experience, a connection to another person unlike any other relationship
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The elders describe it as the experience of a lifetime
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: For people who make it, it even beats the heart-pounding passion of falling in love for the first time
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So making a marriage last may be hard
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the elders also want young people to know that it's worth the effort
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Think small
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: What can you do to keep the spark alive and the marriage interesting for decades?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The elders advise you to think small
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The view from the end tells you that a marriage is made up of hundreds of daily interactions
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In each of those you have a chance to be positive, to be cheerful, to be supportive
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They suggest that you make a habit of doing small, positive things
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: One idea that came up often is doing your partner's chore
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Say it's 6 AM on a cold, rainy morning, the dog is scratching on the bedroom door, and it's your partner's turn to walk him- but you get up and do it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That's money in the bank for the relationship
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Talk, Talk, Talk
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The elders believe that many marital problems can be solved through open communication
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: One man put it colorfully:"Keep yapping at one another."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: According to the elders, the strong, silent type may be initially attractive - but probably doesn't make the best marriage partner
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As one 80-something told me:"If you can't communicate, you're just two dead ducks."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Stop trying to change your partner
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: When
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: you are getting serious about someone
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: , the elders say you must accept your partner as is, or don' t get married
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: You should never say to yourself:"After we're married, she or he will lose weight/get a job/like my family/change heart about having kids"- or any other behavior or attitude you don't like
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Instead
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: ask yourself:"Can I live with this trait for a lifetime
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And at any point in a relationship
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: making your partner a do-it-yourself project only leads to anger and disappointment
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Are we hungry?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Here's one that surprised me
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: When
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: a couple is having an argument that threatens to become a truly major blow-up
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the elders suggest that what you may need is - a sandwich
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: That's right
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: these long-married folks say that you should never argue on an empty stomach
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Offer your partner something to eat when he or she is about to fly off the handle
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: According to the elders, rather than a therapist you may sometimes need a pastrami sandwich or a piece of pie
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It's cheaper and more fun!
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: if
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: you want more wisdom
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: ask the elders in your own life what makes a marriage work!
paragraphs.label: no-unit
